summary: This document is an email chain between court officials discussing public access procedures for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial, which began with jury selection on November 29, 2021. It outlines COVID-19 protocols for attending the trial and notes that outdated information on a website was causing confusion about remote access.

persons.name: Edward Friedland
persons.context: Court official who sends and forwards emails regarding updating public information about trial access procedures and COVID-19 protocols.

persons.name: Joseph Pecorino
persons.context: Court staff member who provides a link to the case information page and is identified as a contact for victims wishing to attend the trial.

persons.name: Matthew Rogers
persons.context: Appears as a recipient in the email chain, but his specific role is not detailed in the text.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the trial (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell) for which the email chain is discussing public access procedures.

connections.description: They are corresponding as court officials to coordinate and correct public information about trial access.
Both are included in the email correspondence regarding court procedures.
Pecorino is a court staff member involved in facilitating public and victim access to Maxwell's trial.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Trial Jury Selection Begins
events.description: Jury selection for the trial of United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell commenced.

events.title: Court Order on Trial Access Procedures
events.description: The S.D.N.Y. Court issued an order outlining procedures for public access to the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

events.title: Updated Court Order on Trial Access
events.description: The S.D.N.Y. Court issued an updated order on procedures for public access to the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

locations: S.D.N.Y. courthouse (United States District Court Southern District of New York)
keyFacts: The trial of Ghislaine Maxwell (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell) began with jury selection on November 29, 2021.
Public access to the trial was to be in-person only, with live feeds available in overflow courtrooms, but no remote telephonic or broadcast access was permitted.
Victims wishing to attend the trial were instructed to contact the U.S. Attorney's Office Victim-Witness Coordinator or Joseph Pecorino of the Court's District Executive Office.
Strict COVID-19 protocols were in place for courthouse entry, including a health questionnaire, temperature check, and mandatory mask-wearing.
An outdated public notice about phone access to the trial was causing confusion, prompting court officials to update the information to reflect the in-person-only policy.
